comments.commentBody:
Hillary Clinton has presence and this is not something one can always explain, but it is important and commands respect, at least for this American.

A rare outing today, a reunion with two friends of forty years, we spoke of many things. The Recession for one, the debate last night briefly, Trump on Saturday Live, which we are skipping, a prize-winning award book on Bob Marley for my godson, a rap musician, and his mother in passing, told me that Carson is in trouble.

Our focus remained on Hillary Clinton. Ask 'Alice' who she is, and I would reply the Red Queen. And it is the most curious thing, but Bernie Sanders, a white knight in slamming the boring email controversy, was able to put an end to this obstacle, and Hillary Clinton is one move forward on the political chessboard, the Democrat hopeful may be in reach of the Crown.

I understand that you're calling Hillary Clinton the "queen" because of her lead in the polls in most states, and her substantial advantage in campaign funds, insider endorsements, and friendly NYT articles. But just as in 2008, the mainstream assumption that Hillary Clinton is an inevitability who's already earned the nomination may come back to hurt her. People start to notice when they see that their false choices are already proscribed before they get to make them.

The DNC clearly wishes it had the power to crown Hillary without the tedious formality of elections. That's why there are so few debates on the Democratic side this cycle. It's also why all the candidates had to sign a pledge agreeing not to appear in any unsanctioned alternative debates.

We've already had one Clinton in charge, in between two Bushes. Our politics are dynastic enough, and the outcomes may be predetermined by insider connections and purchasing power, but we haven't crowned her yet.

Amen, Ms. Ritchie.  I asked myself the same questions about the NYT mandate that everyone must say Clinton won.  For me, the answer is to follow the money - the NYT, like the rest of the big money media, are protecting their wealthy owners and advertisers by promoting the candidate who doesn't propose to tax and regulate them, instead of supporting the real candidate who wants to give this country back to its people.  Please continue to speak up, for everyone's benefit!

Oh no, Mr. Blow, not you too! Did the NYT call a meeting with their staff writers to dictate that the outcome would be, no matter what, that Hillary won this debate? I cannot see one reason to say that her canned, pandering, practiced answers had any redeeming quality whatsoever. I agree with Lincoln Chaffee on one point that he made last night: Hillary's vote authorizing the use of military force in Iraq should disqualify her as a serious candidate.

Bernie Sanders, on the other hand, was authentic and principled. He doesn't need to pander. His convictions are deep, real and haven't changed for all the years he has been in politics.

To me it is truly disturbing that the media is so desperately trying to control the message here, because without all of her billions in super pac money, opinion shapers and other paid surrogates, Hillary would be considered the loser of that debate hands down.
I was with you  in 2008. Hillary is intelligent, well spoken and has all the experience one could hope for in a world leader.

Of course, everyone's views about the participants' respective performances last night are colored in part by their prior feelings about the candidates. Everyone includes me.

I supported Hillary over the President in 2008 and took a number of verbal and physical (it was in good fun) beatings from my late wife for it. But, I thought then as I do now that she is smart, tough and highly qualified to be our President, not just our first woman President. I think President Obama has done a pretty good job, but until he has had nothing to lose in the last year or so, hasn't he disappointed all of you who marched shouting Si Se Puede and Yes We Can? I know I hoped for more.

I truly believe Hillary will do a fine job if elected, better than the President who had little experience in dealing with Congress, world leaders and our zombie media. She has been tested over and over again and is still standing, ready to lead.

I suggest we give her the chance she deserves. No one else on the political scene, Democrat or Republican, is better qualified or equally or more electable. Open your eyes folks.
And that particular quote from Omar was viscerally  on point! As the editrial page pointed out, she came to win.
I love that you quoted the Wire, one of the best TV shows of all time!
Right on! Regrettably the NYT is (again) cheering for the establishment.

Memo:  Being a political leader, being the president, is not about being "sincere."  If that's your goal, write a blog, be a country singer.  It's a dangerous world out there, both domestically and on the international stage, and I'm going with an intelligent, street-smart candidate with international credibility instead of the former mayor of Burlington (one of my favorite places to visit--love the Ben and Jerry's!).

"But all in all, she played it nearly perfectly. "

And that's exactly it; Hillary played it. And that's the exact difference between her and Bernie Sanders. Because Bernie Sanders doesn't have to play it. He is who he is who he is. No matter what state, city, venue he is in, he is authentically and genuinely himself. And that is a man who is consistent, honest, and passionate about his country. He truly cares about the people he represents, and he truly wants to change the terrible direction that the US in going in. When people look at his voting record, they'll see that he has a moral compass that is unwavering; he doesn't change his viewpoint just to gain votes. He votes with his conscience. And that is why he has such a huge amount of support. The NYT (and all the other bought and paid for mainstream news outlets) can call it any way they want; the American people know who the real winner of last nights debate is.

Val in Brooklyn, NY. to MIMA in heartsny.

Wow, such profuse praise. Didn't know we had part of her PR team here. How much does HRC pay you for each endorsement?

Submitted 10-15-15@2:45 a.m. EST

Hillary Clinton has learned what it is like to be in the public eye. She is clearly comfortable in public, and why wouldn't she be? She has been an attorney in courts of law, First Lady to a governor, First Lady to a president, a senator, a Secretary of State. She's been in the company of many a person whether on the campaign trail in Iowa or at a state dinner abroad. Would we really expect her to be a wallflower or a doormat? She wasn't searching for a way to bring a flame of vengeance to get back at someone for insulting her face. She wasn't telling lies about an agency that is devoted to women taking charge of their reproductive abilities. She wasn't telling tales about the death of a child, misleading the listeners. She was so much more what women really want, as the movie line goes, than another woman on the stage a few weeks ago.

If we are looking to a woman to become our next president, Hillary Clinton has spoken about issues with details, with skill, with knowledge she has learned first hand. Hillary Clinton has been in the limelight of a political world for a lifetime. She has learned her way through the world of hard knocks. She spoke with tact, respect, and skill last night. That's not anything she needs to defend herself about it or be at the center of critics.

She did what she is good at - and we say - good for her. However, she's not running to call herself the first woman president for that sake, she's running because she has what it takes.

We will all see Elizabeth Warren in front of a surging, adoring audience arm and arm with Hillary Clinton, hands joined reaching for the roof. In celebration of a new Democratic president and our first woman president. We should fully expect to see this in the campaign. And for those who would never believe that such a thing could happen can take this post as an early warning.
Israel is a hotbed of racism.

Mr. De Blasio, (nee Warren Wilhelm), is the mayor of New York City, a municipality with no say in foreign affairs. He has no business making an official visit to Israel.

I hear that he plans on lecturing on antisemitism while in Israel. Isn't he preaching to the choir? I didn't think that Israel was a hotbed of anti-semitism.

The NYT had this piece written before the debate.  She was going to be the winner regardless of how reality played out.  I just wonder how long the NYT will stay in business, it's time to put this Old Grey Lady in the nursing home and close the door.

@Tammy Sue: It's no surprise that the corporate-owned media is doing everything it can to promote their representative. Hillary IS Wall Street. Hillary is a corporate stooge. The first woman president should not be Hillary.

We women should wait for a better representative.

Great piece by Robert Scheer in truthdig: http://www.truthdig.com/report/item/go_ahead_back_hillary_clinton_and_fo...

"And how much closer we are to 1984 than we thought."

Pretty close. What the punditocracy has not been able to hide is the incredible attendance records at Sanders' rallies. He announced that he raised over $1.5 million during the debate.

Underlying Hillary Clinton's "spectacular" performance was complex web of newly adopted me-too policy planks, mischaracterizations of her record, exaggeration of her role in pivotal events, and evasion of responsibility for her role in the greatest foreign policy debacle in American history.

The good news is that the major social media sites seem to indicate that the people saw through this ham-handed ruse. The bad news is that The Times and CNN seem oddly and creepily intent on dissuading us from our own perceptions, and pushing push a counter-narrative where up is down, black is white, and Hillary Clinton "crushed it." Thus the real story here is in the marked disparity between the public's perception and the punditocracy's. And how much closer we are to 1984 than we thought.

She forgets that during her husbands Presidency they wanted to implement a Universal healthcare program, not too dissimilar from Denmarks or any other country which has a similar system. Of course, when they realized it did not have a chance of making it through the legislature, they withdrew it. Deep down, she wants what Bernie wants. It is about politics and getting elected
not necessarily saying or doing what is right.

The Saudis got off cheap. The standard American graft system always insists on at least a tenth of a point on graft, so Bill & Hill should have insisted on $20 million. Somewhere, Maurice Stans is feeling insulted.

Right on Charles.

"You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows"
This is inflammatory and uses no evidence to support mere allegations.  I'm disappointed it got past the review process and posted in the comments.

Understanding the legal and privacy issues that are part of these accounts, I'd ask the author to cite the source for the 10 year old boy's judicially approved marriage (state, county, judge's name and any other public record information) as well as that for any other cases the author deems egregious.

Agree with you. He should look to clean the city streets
The city has never been as dirty as it is now.

He hasn't appointed key replacements in essential city roles, homeless shelters and support services have shut down due to lack of payment by the city, his tale of two cities is quickly becoming one big mess, yet he has time to visit Israel and Palestine? Didn't he just visit the Vatican and the Pope?

de Blasio is going to be a one term Mayor if he doesn't get his act together. Does he think he's going to be Governor or President? de Blasio is quickly becoming the next Dinkins.

Actually I thought Bernie was both pragmatic and cogent on the on the guns issue. With roots, family and friends in Texas I am fully aware of how quickly hysteria and irrational paranoia can set in when the subject is broached. (The NRA has done a spectacular job of ensuring that is basically impossible to have a discussion.) Listening to Bernie... I sense he knows better than the others how to break through that impasse and start a real conversation that leads to real outcomes.

But it's AOK for the Republicans to constantly offer tax cuts. Free money! It's gonna do you a lotta good when everybody has more money and the price of all the stuff you were going to buy with all that free money the Republicans gave now cost more such that you can only afford to buy the same stuff you could buy before... and the roads are pothole minefields, and the bridges are falling into the river, and the schools are churning out kid who know how to pass the last test they were taught to and nothing else!

But giving out "free money" in the form of tax cuts, that's so much better for society than society getting a free education.
Well, he may still want to run in his home state again as he is not likely to become president.

Sen. Sanders was impressive. Sec. Clinton did very well, I still have a trust problem with her especially when she walks into a roomful of bankers and tells them to "knock it off." O.K. that did not do the trick. O'Malley could have put himself on the V.P. consideration list if he can be consistent from here on out. Not the short list, but the list. Gov. Chafee was far to nervous, but genuine. Sen. Webb was well spoken and delivered his message, I wonder how he would do in the polls if he was running as a Republican, I think he would be doing alright, he just does not behave like a Republican. I vote Sen. Sanders in the primary and will vote for any Dem. nominee in the general.

As the Editorial notes, it was unbelievably refreshing to hear a "reality based" discussion of issues that actually have an impact on the lives of most Americans.  And it's equally disturbing that no one in the GOP camp has spent the last 24 hours dodging and weaving to avoid even acknowledging those issues, while keeping up a steady patter of ad hominem snarks and sneers.  Democrats are often as guilty as Republicans of catering to Wall Street and moneyed interests, but at least they're willing to publicly put the problem on the table.

Wow! An American politician actually willing to show a sliver of open-ness to the millions of Palestinians occupied and subjugated by Israel!

Sorry! Gaza is free!
No toys you naught Gazans! And maybe 5 or maybe 6 things we'll (that'd be Israel) allow in to your "free" land. Nothing out of course. Really now!

Hey Gazans, want to reconstruct the thousands of homes and the schools and hospitals we blew up in our last invasion?
Nyah nyah! Keep waiting!

As they say to little kids, "it doesn't matter who started it."

Keep Israel strong, absolutely.

But don't allow it to bludgeon others into 21st century oblivion.

Hope the Mayor's visit provides some respite to Palestinians and some sanity to the Israel / Palestinian madness!

I had a similar thought on viewing the picture with regards to the headline, at least.  The 'big tent' consists of four old men and one old woman.  Where are the african americans, the hispanics, the young to middle aged?  There seems to be a much more diverse group of candidates in the GOP than in the 'party of diversity'.
The subject is dietary guidelines for the 90% of the population who are not diabetic, perhaps?

Yes, civility was the big winner last night, something we haven't seen coming from any of the Republican pseudo candidates.

After watching Hillary Clinton show her command of the issues and being able to articulate them as a President, she is without a doubt the biggest winner.

I'd say the biggest losers hands down are all of the Bozo's that have been appearing in the GOP Gong Show, otherwise known as the Republican forum, debate or amateur hour for clowns.....it's no contest.
